ygData.subject: Re: HyperNEAT Outputs for Stock Trading

Todd,

Given your eventual goal of predicting various time stages, it seems=

like HyperNEAT may actually be worthwhile.  However, I think creating
the =
substrate for a single agent will prove to be quite challenging. 
I know fa=
r less about stock trading than I probably should, but from
what I do know,=
 it seems as though there aren't that many regularities
you could build int=
o the substrate, which somewhat defeats the point
in using HyperNEAT.  Neve=
rtheless, I would be interested in hearing
how you planned to lay out the s=
ubstrate, as you probably know more
about the regularities in the domain th=
an me.

As for the questions in your initial post:

1.  Again, I'm no stock=
 expert, but I think if you are using HyperNEAT
and there is a regularity a=
mongst the outputs it might be a good idea
to use multiple outputs.  If you=
 put the sell node at -1, the buy node
a +1, and nothing at 0, do the other=
 nodes logically fit in anywhere?
 Of course, this is just me thinking, so =
my ultimate answer is "try
both."  As far as forcing binary output, can't y=
ou just do something
like "if (output>.5) return 1; else return 0;"?

2.  I=
f you know a priori that 3% is a good threshold for activity, you
may want =
to try that, but I'm not sure that it is easier to predict
percent change o=
r to make a classification, intuitively it seems like
the latter would be e=
asier, but I'd still recommend trying both or
asking someone with more expe=
rience in the stock trading domain.

3.  Recurrence can look back as many t=
imesteps as necessary.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Todd Owen" <jtoddowen=
@...> wrote:
>
> Petar,
> 
> I like the fact HyperNEAT uses nodes with diff=
ering activation
> functions (sine, abs, etc.) instead of just sigmoid.  My=
 understanding
> is NEAT only uses sigmoid.
> 
> Also, my eventual goal is =
to evolve an agent in a single time frame,
> say daily, then create a role =
which uses weekly, daily, and hourly
> agents in much the same way as the r=
ecent multi-agent paper discussed.  
> 
> You are correct the geometric reg=
ularity is not as strong as the
> typical robotic examples, but I was intri=
gued by HN's ability to
> scale.  I will look into NEAT by itself though.
>=
 
> --Todd
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_cher=
venski@>
> wrote:
> >
> > Well I don't understand what does HyperNEAT to do=
 with it. Unless you 
> > believe there is some geometric regularities in t=
hose time series 
> > there is no point to use HyperNEAT. Try regular NEAT =
first.
> >
>
